It seems as though you're just making a convection oven... Using heat doesn't, in fact dehydrate, but cooks.

To make a real dehydrator, you can take a box fan, and some residential air filters, place said air filters on the side to the fan that the air flows from.. Use a bungee chord or 2 to secure. Turn on fan, and viola! A true dehydrator. You put what you want to dehydrate in the slats of the air filter.

It seems you'd be better off buying an actual dehydrator that stores more food and can maintain the desired temperature inside so you don't constantly run a heater. There's also less risk from the sketchy wiring and heat lamp in a cardboard box.

Nice video, your spray painting technique definitely could use some work tho, lol, try holding the can about 8-10" away from the surface you're painting, and make longer strokes, starting beyond the edge of your work on one side and moving all the way past the edge on the other, take your time and do it in 2-3 coats and you'll end up with a nice even layer of paint with no streaks.

AYYY LOVING THE INTRO

That bulb is WAY over powered. You don't want light when dehydrating and you absolutely don't want heat much over 120 degrees F. You can dehydrate very effectively with just the fan and/or a small solar thermal collector isolated from the main box. You do NOT want to cook the food when dehydrating, especially meat. Dehydrated cooked meat can become contaminated by botulism WHICH IS LETHAL! Keep your jerky under 200 degrees.

Improvements:
1. Add a filter on the air intake.
2. The lamp should be placed above the food since a lot of food will drip while drying.
3. Add a pan in the bottom that will collect said drippings from food.
4. While cardboard is cheap, use some other easily accessible material that is less known to be sensitive to moisture.
5. Hot air rises. So air should be forced in from the top and be let out from the bottom side.
